emailColumn.title: 24TLL: Slow but Steady Wins from Home Success to Global E-commerce SaaS

authorInfo.title: About the Author
authorInfo.description: Yury Shishkin is the founder of 24TLL, an e-commerce automation and design agency that successfully pivoted to SaaS products and expanded internationally from 2017 onwards. Starting with LG as an anchor client in Dubai, Yury methodically built operations across UAE, Netherlands, Mexico, and Indonesia while navigating geopolitical challenges, cultural differences, and market-specific requirements. His experience spans agency services to SaaS product development, with 10 products launched and 4 surviving. Yury currently operates from Dubai while managing a global team across multiple time zones, embodying the challenges and opportunities of international B2B expansion in the e-commerce technology sector.

keyTakeaways.title: Strategic Lessons for International E-commerce SaaS Expansion
keyTakeaways.description: 24TLL's expansion journey reveals crucial insights for B2B SaaS companies entering international markets. Key lessons include: Client-led expansion provides the safest entry strategy - following existing clients to new markets reduces risk and provides immediate revenue. Local entity establishment is essential for enterprise sales - big clients prefer local partners for tax, VAT, and compliance reasons. Cultural nuances can make or break business relationships - understanding that 'no' doesn't exist in Latin America while 'yes' is coded differently requires deep local integration. Timezone management becomes critical when operating across 4+ markets simultaneously. Community building and reputation development must be prioritized over direct sales in international markets. Budget allocation should account for 6-12 month sales cycles and higher than expected local hiring costs. The spray-and-pray approach teaches fast but costs significantly - validation before scaling is essential for sustainable growth.

emails.subject: 'Discovery': How LG Opened Our Dubai Door in 2017
emails.greeting: Hey there. How are you doing?
emails.body: I promised you to share my story of 24TLL and its expansion. This week I have some kind of vacation, so it would be nice to dive into the memories and write some letters to you ğŸ“. If you have any additional questions, feel free to ask. Maybe our experience will help new founders to avoid some mistakes. First idea of expanding came to us in around 2017. At that point, we were already quite active as an agency working with big businesses at home ğŸ¢, and things were moving along pretty well. Around that time, we started positioning ourselves as "product and services." That is, we weren't just offering services related to e-commerce and design around it, but we also began developing some automation in the form of scripts and so on ğŸ¤–. These thoughts were, of course, a bit dreamlike at the time ğŸ’­. But circumstances lined upâ€”one of our clients was relocated to Dubai (where I am now) ğŸ—ï¸. I think that was one of the decisive factors. They recommended us and said, "Let's try something here, because you've been serving us at home for the last five years, and your work is significantly better than what's available locally in Dubai. Let's give it a shot" ğŸ¯. So, we flew over, started testing, and tried working in a sort of business trip mode â€” fly in, meet, get some briefs, deliver services, and fulfill orders âœˆï¸. It all moved forward in a slow, steady way. It was almost the same work we were doing at home, just for the Dubai region. The client was the same â€” LG. A manager had relocated; he worked at a subsidiary ad agency, and we were subcontractors both at home, and, eventually, in Dubai ğŸ¤.

highlight.title: The Golden Client Strategy: Following Your Best Customers Around the World
highlight.description: Sometimes the best business strategy isn't trying to find new customers - it's following your existing ones! Yury discovered that when your best client moves to a new country, they become your perfect ambassador. It's like having a friend introduce you at a new school - they already know you're awesome and can tell everyone else. This approach removes the biggest challenge of international expansion: proving yourself to strangers. Instead of cold calling, you have a warm recommendation from someone who already trusts your work!

emails.subject: 'Lessons': Why Big Clients Need Local Partners
emails.greeting: Hello, my friend. I'm continuing my letters with some more important topics to paint the picture.
emails.body:
Since 2015 we are focused on large clients ğŸ¢. Pre-2019: agency services. Post-2019: repackaged as SaaS. We've launched 10 products; 4 survived ğŸ“Š.

When we pivoted from an agency business to an IT business, I realized the IT side had a foundation for scaling âš¡. That is, you can sell the same product multiple times across different markets. It can even work remotely. That's when we understood we needed to look toward Europe ğŸŒ.

And by 2022, we'd spent a long time preparing to enter the European market, doing everything necessary. In the first year, we set up a legal entity in the Netherlands ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡± and began a similar pathâ€”business trips, meetings, product showcasesâ€”trying to break into Europe.

In the Netherlands we had the same model, but we leveraged our home experience and Hatch's reputation. You need open entities in the Netherlands, for example, if you already had Dubai because cross-country invoicing is messy ğŸ“‹. Big clients prefer local partners (taxes, VAT reclaim) ğŸ’°. Local presence is the key for enterprise ğŸ”‘.

We started participating in conferences like GITEX. That's where the idea opened up that it's not just the MENA region or Europe â€” we began attending Web Summit, and participated three times ğŸª. It was more of a startup scene, but we still tried finding clients there.

highlight.title: The Enterprise Reality Check: Why Local Entities Beat Remote Operations
highlight.description: Big companies are like careful parents - they want to work with 'local' businesses they can trust and understand! Yury learned that enterprise clients don't just prefer local partners, they practically require them. It's about more than just comfort - it's about taxes, legal stuff, and making sure everything follows the rules. Imagine trying to convince a big company to work with someone who lives far away and might disappear - much easier when you have a real office and legal presence in their country. It's like the difference between buying from a neighborhood store versus ordering from a mysterious website!

emails.subject: 'Research': UAE vs Netherlands vs The World
emails.body: So we see it's necessary to establish entities in a country you want to work with big clients ğŸ¢. It's logical to start research and try new markets. Here is some nice relevant experience to share. The UAE has been steady since 2016 ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª. Netherlands ramped up in 2020 ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡±. We pivoted fully to the UAE by mid-2022. On the one hand, Europe was tied to our partnership with Hatch, a Dutch IT company ğŸ¤. We became their official reseller at home, and then deepened collaboration to co-develop products for Europe. The Netherlands was the logical base. Plus, Europe's e-commerce maturity: higher purchasing power, average order value, GMV â€” made it attractive ğŸ’°. But it's also conservative and competitive. On the other hand we have almost no competitors in Dubai ğŸ¯. Post-invasion: we considered the U.S. ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸, Portugal ğŸ‡µğŸ‡¹, Asia, LatAm ğŸŒ. We split efforts â€” Mexico ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½, Indonesia ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡©, UAE ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª. Mexico (Spanish-speaking LATAM gateway) cost ~$130K, yielded one client ğŸ’¸. Mexico was seen as a stepping stone to the U.S., but cultural friction ("maÃ±ana" attitude) hurt. My sister (Anna Shishkina) co-ran an accelerator (Hacker Sprint) in Chile/Mexico/Brazil and praised Mexico's business climate. I thought it'd be a U.S. proxy â€” I was wrong ğŸ˜…. Brazil might be better â€” we're now integrating with Magazine Luiza ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·. Indonesia: the Dubai client moved there, so we followed ğŸ‘¥. Indonesia (270M people, fast-growing e-commerce) has 6 clients (Samsung, Panasonic), but small checks ğŸ“±. Indonesia: huge population, booming e-commerce, low competition. A client connection helped. We're now expanding from there to Singapore/Malaysia ğŸŒ.

highlight.title: The Portfolio Approach: Why Smart Entrepreneurs Test Multiple Markets
highlight.description: Instead of putting all his eggs in one basket, Yury was smart and tried several countries at once - like planting different types of seeds to see which ones grow best! He discovered that Europe has lots of money but also lots of competition (like a crowded marketplace), while Dubai has less competition but you have to work harder to find customers. Mexico seemed like it would be easy because of family connections, but culture is tricky and can surprise you. The key lesson: try several places at once, but don't expect them all to work the same way!

emails.subject: Mistakes: Our $100K U.S. Learning Experience
emails.body: Moving on. Of course we had some "bad experiences" or I can say "lessons learned" ğŸ“š. Sometimes it costs a fortune, but for you and your future readers it's free â˜º We didn't set any budgets or deadlines, decisions were intuitive ğŸ¤”. We'd wait for a crisis or clear signal to stop. In the U.S., the team lead also felt the lack of results, and we refocused on the booming home market ğŸ . There was a mistake in the U.S. strategy that I should mention: lack of experience in new markets ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸. We thought a 1â€“2 person team could work, but enterprise sales require systemic effort ğŸ’¼. Breaking into big players like Samsung or LG is nearly impossible without something extraordinary ğŸš€. The U.S. is hyper-competitive (Salesforce, SAP dominate). Big brands are hard to crack in the U.S. And we can't target adjacent segments because our tools solve pain points for big brands managing multichannel inventory (Amazon, eBay, etc.) ğŸ“¦. SMBs can hire two people to handle this â€” they don't need our solution. Costs of U.S. effort: around $50Kâ€“$100K â€” salaries, travel, exhibits ğŸ’°. We saw the U.S. as a promising point. The Netherlands was a stepping stone. In 2019, I even opened a U.S. entity (Delaware), did a roadshow, attended NRF in Chicago, and hired a small biz-dev team ğŸš‚. But after a year and significant spending, it went nowhere. Sad but true ğŸ˜”.

highlight.title: The Reality of Enterprise Sales: Why Two People Can't Crack Giants
highlight.description: Yury learned a very expensive lesson about trying to fight giants with a tiny army! Think of it like trying to win a soccer game with only 2 players against a full team of 11 - it's almost impossible. Big companies in America have LOTS of people trying to sell to them, including huge companies like Salesforce that have thousands of salespeople. Sending just 1-2 people to compete is like bringing a water gun to a sword fight. Sometimes the lesson is worth $100K because it teaches you what NOT to do - and that wisdom can save you millions later!

emails.subject: Shock: When 'No' Doesn't Exist and 'Yes' is Coded
emails.body:
Today we speak about Indonesia & Mexico and some cultural things that affect business ğŸŒ. Going international expects working with different nationalities. It's better to learn some cultural nuances before you face them in your business (or ruin your business because of them). Maybe we should create a book called "Cultural nuances for business"? I'm sure it will be quite thick ğŸ“–.

The decision to move to Indonesia came at that moment: September, mobilization, the guys are here in Dubai ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª. October, we're all sitting in a rented apartment, like, "how do we even live, my guys?" And I'm like, "Okay, this feels surreal, let's do something" ğŸ . So we just decided, "Let's try Indonesia", without any grand reasoning. Just: (1) we potentially have a client there, (2) it's a big market ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡©.

For Mexico, same logic â€” and we sent Gen to check it out ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½. The idea was: we're in Dubai, Mexico, Indonesia â€” let's see where traction happens, then double down ğŸ¯. That was the plan. But once we landed, the first six months were wild. Both markets welcomed us warmly. We quickly got in front of the right people. They'd say, "Cool product, very interesting" ğŸ‘. We got carried away, thinking contracts were around the corner.

Turns out, in all these countries, basic feedback like "You're great guys" means nothing ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸. We took it as validation, but it was just politeness. Mexicans, I think, literally can't say "no" âŒ.

Later I got that: "no" doesn't exist in Latin America. But here's the kicker: they don't say "yes" either ğŸ¤¯. There's even a YouTube video on how to say "yes" properly here. If you say "sim (yes)", they instantly peg you as a foreigner. Their "yes" and "no" are coded differently â€” neither is direct.

Costs. Mexico was the priciest in salaries ğŸ’°. English-speaking Mexicans = $4k/month. Indonesia: $1k. Dubai: $2.5kâ€“$3k.

highlight.title: The Politeness Trap: When 'Great Product' Doesn't Mean 'I'll Buy It'
highlight.description: Yury discovered that different cultures have completely different ways of being polite - and this can trick business people! In Mexico, people are SO nice that they can't say 'no' directly, but they also don't say 'yes' the way you expect. It's like having a secret code that only locals understand. When someone says 'cool product, very interesting,' Americans think that means 'I want to buy it!' But in other cultures, it might just mean 'I'm being polite and don't want to hurt your feelings.' Learning these cultural codes is like learning the rules of different games - you need to understand them to play successfully!

emails.subject: Strategy: Managing 4 Markets and 4 Time Zones
emails.body:
I like this topic; it's about people and management ğŸ‘¥. After we made the decision to move to those countries, we had to split the team, mostly by dialogue and logic. We fractured into 4 businesses: mature home + 3 chaotic startups. Now it's a "Home + global startup" ğŸŒ.

Biz-dev splits into three: 1) contact miners (LinkedIn scraping) ğŸ”, 2) SDRs (emails/WhatsApp) ğŸ“§, 3) account execs (closing) ğŸ¤. We tried doing it ourselves, but broken English/local distrust killed us. In Dubai, we hired Syrians, Iranians, Indians ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª.

Mexico fits Genâ€”he's into football âš½, the culture. We even had a Mexican working for us in the CIS. So we decided that Gen is taking this market ğŸ‡²ğŸ‡½. He went with a local Mexican tooâ€”they knew the drill. There were a dozen hires (even remote Paraguayans). Mexicans were the toughest. No feedback tolerance. Eventually, we pared back to Gen and JosÃ©.

Indonesia vibed with Tyoma - Bali, all that ğŸï¸. It keeps 3â€“4 locals + remote eastern europeans. Indonesians: chill but responsible ğŸ˜Œ.

The rest (CTO, ops) stayed close to us for timezone alignment â°. All production and support are still there.

Hiring: LinkedIn (1k Dubai apps/day) ğŸ’¼. Firing: by the book. Zero guilt â€” they never felt they underperformed.

Outsourcing: to hire locals we used agencies, local only ğŸ¢. Language is everything ğŸ—£ï¸.

Tried lead gen agencies ($5k/month for meetings) ğŸ’°. First month: great. Then: ghosted ğŸ‘». Europe, Mexico, Brazil â€” same story. Hired two in Brazil pre-entity â€” even got PR coverage (search "24 TTL" in Portuguese) ğŸ“°.

highlight.title: The Personality-Market Match: Why Cultural Fit Beats Pure Skills
highlight.description: Yury made a brilliant discovery about international teams: match people's personalities to the cultures they'll work in! Gen loved football and Mexican culture, so he became the Mexico guy. Tyoma liked the chill Bali lifestyle, so he handled Indonesia. It's like casting actors for different movie roles - you want someone who naturally fits the part. When your team members actually ENJOY and understand the culture they're working with, they do much better than someone who's just skilled but doesn't connect with the local vibe. Cultural enthusiasm beats technical skills every time!

emails.subject: Lessons: Priorities, Mistakes, and Timezone Hell
emails.body:
We've gone through all the things I wanted to share with you. And this letter is a kind of summary ğŸ“.

We had to manage four markets at once, it was quite difficult ğŸ˜…. Gen complained I ignored Mexico (timezone hell) ğŸ•. Indonesia was easier (+4h). We had syncs at weird hours. We also had a "Growth Director" overseeing expansion â€” big mistake: too early to delegate ğŸš«. Year one, I was barely involved in biz-dev ops. Reports sounded rosy ("Meetings! Connections!"), but no revenue ğŸ’¸.

After 1.5 years, we pivoted hard: slashed teams, hyper-focused on deals ğŸ¯. Reputation mattersâ€”B2B relies on trust, relationships ğŸ¤. We didn't invest in community-building (forums, academies, awards) like we do now. At home, reputation grew organically; abroad, CIS founders faced extra hurdles. So, the biggest lesson: reputation first, sales second ğŸ†.

Talking about priorities, I can put it like this:
Dubai #1 (I'm here daily) ğŸ‡¦ğŸ‡ª.
Indonesia #2 (timezone) ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡©.
Home (steady ops) ğŸ .
Mexico is "the neglected child": I'd take late calls, but zero focus ğŸ˜´.

Our Biggest mistakes:
Spray-and-pray taught us fast, but cost a lot ğŸ’°.
Should've validated first, scaled later. Now we test Korea with 1 FT + 2 interns ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡·.
Timezone sprawl hurts too â°.

Surprising winning: community-building ğŸ˜ï¸. Only Tyoma and I believed; Indonesia exploded. Now it's our #1 B2B lever. Also, meta-events (IDRF forum) â€” we underestimated their power. Now we're all-in ğŸš€.

That's all for now, we've done great stepsâ€¦ Guess what country I am going to explore next? Tickets are already bought; vacation turns into an exciting business trip âœˆï¸.

highlight.title: The Founder's Dilemma: Why You Can't Delegate International Expansion Too Early
highlight.description: Yury learned a super important lesson about being a leader: you can't give away the most important jobs too early! He hired a 'Growth Director' to handle expansion, thinking he could focus on other things. But it's like asking someone else to make friends for you - it just doesn't work the same way. The reports sounded great ('We had lots of meetings!') but no actual business happened. Founders have special magic when talking to customers - they have passion, knowledge, and can make decisions instantly. Other people can help, but in the beginning, the founder HAS to be the one building those first important relationships!
